name: Laurel (Bay)

etymology.derivation: Named after nymph Daphne who transformed into laurel

description: Sacred to Apollo, god of prophecy, poetry, and healing. The laurel became Apollo's sacred plant when the nymph Daphne transformed into a laurel tree while fleeing his pursuit. Symbol of victory, prophecy, purification, and poetic inspiration.

mythologicalOrigin.story: Daphne, pursued by love-struck Apollo, prayed to Gaia/Peneus for escape. Transformed into laurel tree at moment of capture. Apollo, heartbroken, declared laurel sacred to him forever.
mythologicalOrigin.symbolism: Eternal love, transformation, refuge, divine consolation prize
mythologicalOrigin.result: Laurel became Apollo's sacred crown, symbol, and oracular medium

uses: Victory crowns - Pythian Games victors crowned with laurel wreaths
Prophetic rituals - Delphic Oracle chewed laurel leaves, burned as incense
Purification - laurel branches sprinkled with water for cleansing
Temple decoration - fresh laurel adorned Apollo's temples and altars
Poetic inspiration - poets crowned with laurel when composing
Healing - aromatic leaves in medicinal preparations under Apollo's patronage
Protection - hung above doorways to ward off evil and lightning
rituals: Pythian Games - athletic and artistic victors crowned with sacred laurel
Delphic Oracle - Pythia chewed laurel, sat on tripod over vapors, inhaled smoke
Purification rites - laurel water sprinkled on people and sacred spaces
Apollo festivals - processions carrying laurel branches
Poetic contests - victorious poets receive laurel crown (poet laureate)
Healing ceremonies - laurel burned as incense in Asclepian temples
sacredSignificance: Most sacred plant to Apollo. Laurel = prophetic power and divine inspiration. Pythia's laurel-induced visions guided Greek civilization. Crown of laurel = highest honor. Poet laureate tradition continues today. Symbol that love can transform into eternal devotion.
culturalContext: Laurel wreaths = ancient Nobel Prize. Athletes, poets, generals crowned. Roman emperors wore laurel crowns (Caesar, Augustus). Academic honors: baccalaureate = 'laurel berries.' Olympic victors originally received olive, Pythian victors laurel.
preparationMethods: Culinary: dried leaves for cooking (Mediterranean cuisine staple)
Prophetic incense: burn dried leaves on charcoal
Laurel oil: infuse leaves in olive oil for ritual anointing
Wreaths: weave fresh branches for crowns and decoration
Tea: 2-3 leaves in hot water for digestion
Tincture: alcohol extraction for medicinal use
Bath: boil leaves, add to purification bath

growingConditions.form: Evergreen tree or large shrub, 10-60 feet
growingConditions.pruning: Tolerates heavy pruning, good for topiary

safetyWarnings: large medicinal doses may cause drowsiness
NOT California Bay Laurel (Umbellularia) - different plant, toxic in quantity
